From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: schnee

Alemannic German

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • schnee, schné, schnia, schnei, schnìj

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German snê, from Old High German snēo, from Proto-West Germanic *snaiw.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ʃneː/

Noun

[edit]

Schnee m (plural Schnee, diminutive Schneeli or Schneewli)

  1. snow

German

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German snê, from Old High German snēo, from Proto-West Germanic *snaiw.[1]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ʃneː/
  • Rhymes: -eː
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)
  • Hyphenation: Schnee

Noun

[edit]

Schnee m (strong, genitive Schnees, no plural)

  1. (uncountable, meteorology) snow
    Der Schnee schmilzt wegen des heißen Wetters.
    The snow is melting because of the hot weather.
  2. (uncountable, figuratively) snow (static on TV set etc.)
  3. (uncountable, slang) cocaine

Declension

[edit]
Declension of Schnee [sg-only, masculine, strong]
singular
indef. def. noun
nominative ein der Schnee
genitive eines des Schnees
dative einem dem Schnee
accusative einen den Schnee

Synonyms

[edit]
  • (static on the TV): Rauschen n

Hyponyms

[edit]
  • Altschnee
  • Apfelschnee
  • Birnenschnee
  • Eierschnee
  • Eischnee
  • Firnschnee
  • Flugschnee
  • Hartschnee
  • Hexenschnee
  • Kartoffelschnee
  • Kunstschnee
  • Nassschnee
  • Neuschnee
  • Pulverschnee
  • Tiefschnee

Derived terms

[edit]
  • schneeig

Related terms

[edit]

  • Schneebesen

  • Schneeblindheit

  • Schneeschauer
  • Schneeschmelze

  • Schneesturm

  • schneeweiß
  • Schneewittchen
  • Schneeziege

See also

[edit]
  • schneien

Hunsrik

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German snê, from Old High German snēo, from Proto-West Germanic *snaiw.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈʃneː/
  • Rhymes: -eː
  • Syllabification: Schnee

Noun

[edit]

Schnee m

  1. snow

Related terms

[edit]
  • schnëe (“to snow”)

Further reading

[edit]
  • Boll, Piter Kehoma (2021), “Schnee”, in Dicionário Hunsriqueano Riograndense–Português, 3rd edition (overall work in Portuguese), Ivoti: Riograndenser Hunsrickisch, page 144

Pennsylvania German

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German snê, from Old High German snēo, from Proto-West Germanic *snaiw.

Noun

[edit]

Schnee m

  1. snow

Plautdietsch

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle Low German snê, from Old Saxon snēo, from Proto-West Germanic *snaiw.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ʃnɔɪ/

Noun

[edit]

Schnee m

  1. snow
